The deco of the restaurant was simple yet elegant. The surrounding area made us feel like we're not in Singapore. Menu is limited for both food and beverages. The food took quite awhile to arrive, but it was quite delicious when it did. We had double boiled chicken consommé with spinach ricotta tortellini ($10) as appetizer, the soup was not impressive to me but I loved the tortellini. Ordered caesar salad ($16) too but really disappointed at it, the smoked chicken was really dry, had pungent smell and the dressing was so terrible. Both main courses we ordered; orange miso cod mignon with collagen broth ($34) and honey roasted spatchcock ($30) were especially stellar.The only letdown was that I found the cod way too small and a bit cold when served but still good, it's so good that I wish it's a little bigger, then my tummy would be happier. The honey roasted spatchcock was amazingly moist, awesome glazing with marination infused into the meat perfectly. I had Vineyard Signature ($16) as my cocktail that night, tasted pretty unique and new to me, was worth ordering. However, I couldn't taste the alcohol at first and then one of the waiters admitted that they usually would give lower amount of alcohol initially but free of charge if customers desire a stronger drink (like me, duh).In conclusion, it's a good place away from the city, definitely an excellent venue and will leave you a pleasant experience but if food has always been your main focus above all else, I don't think you'd enjoy visiting this place. I'd probably go back for the drinks.

I have to say, absolutely terrible here. The food was terrible - the bull frog leg took 30 minutes to come and then, a miserable amount and a miserable size. The food we came for was not available - beef, duck etc. We ordered the Kids Burger expecting a decent sized one but we got two minute pieces of dry bread, cheese, tomato and beef forced together with a toothpick holding it all together. Not to mention when we first entered the waiters took about 15 minutes to finally hand us the menu... We asked for some water but took over 5 minutes for the request to be sent through, through the second waiter (the first one never sent through our request). We asked for some bowls to share the soup but everyone completely ignored us, had to take the bowls ourselves. Waiter took my soup spoon despite a bowl of soup right in front of me. At the end of the meal, the waitress bumped into me but never apologized... Overall, I think that the standard of service can be improved.

Disappointing to say the least. 4 of the 5 brunch items we ordered, any one with a fridge and a frying pan could probably prepare himself, and save himself an arm and a leg. Only the braised short ribs were OK, but then they obviously have kitchen issues as the sandwich came cold, probably from sitting on the counter too long, waiting for the truffle fries to be ready. Service also nothing much to comment about, mostly non existent. They've got a nice ambience in a secluded location that is not over run by people. That's the only major plus point.
Disappointingly average. Slow service. Limited choice. Items not arrive. You can get so much better these days elsewhere. Go to Common Man or the Lokal!

Located at the rather secluded Hort Park, I wasn't even sure this place existed as the whole park was dark and seemed closed!I was there for a friend's birthday so we made reservations. The service there is top-notch, we had a very attentive waiter who gave us good recommendations and was very friendly.Food is quite good, bit of an odd mix of Thai and Western food. It's a little pricey, but the ambiance of the place was very nice, and it wasn't too noisy and crowded so I quite enjoyed my dinner there.

Overpriced, very inadequate food.  Ambiance isn't bad, but that's the only thing going for it.  I wish I had my $117 (for two) and 2 hours of my life back.  I see this place not lasting more than a couple more months, if lucky, at least on it's own merits.

The rare morning drizzle and breeze in tropical Singapore has made the 3-min sheltered walk from Redhill MRT to Zi Yean no longer drudgery but rather a relaxing trip.    The small while tiles on the wall and the slightly cramped space really reminded me of the old Hong Kong style-the best for a dim sum feast.Overall: Great Dim sum! The best part is that they are not stingy on the ingredients at all! For prawn dumplings, there are literally three fresh and nicely steamed prawn inside! Even for siew mai there's a small prawn in! Same goes for cheong fun, giving you a mouthful of delight.My favorites: Siew mai: fresh and soft with a prawn at the bottom. Not so heavy seasoned so you can enjoy the full body of a siew mai without feeling thirsty afterwardsBlack bean pork rib: the portion is huge with quite some small ribs which come with few bones! The best part is instead of using yam, pumpkin was put in at the bottom which give the ribs a special aroma. The less dry pumpkin also makes the rib a bit more moist, allowing the full contact with your taste buds, hence maximizing the impact of the taste.Price: $2.5 dollars for every single dim sum if you check the bill before 11am! Such value for money! Area for improvement: Some of the dim sum could be more seasoned. The skin of prawn dumplings is a little too thick. Overall great dim sum with great friends as company! Highly recommend!

The dim sum here rocks. It's worth the walking and trudging under the sun to get to the location. But of course if someone's driving then it's ideal.We had a department 'gathering' and my boss recommended this place. It's his favourite dim sum location.  The restaurant is separated into two areas, one air-conditioned, one without. They each provide different experiences: the air-con one for the big family gatherings and 'more formal' dinners; the non air-con for the authentic Cantonese kopitiam-styled dim sum.The service staff were probably more attentive in the air-con restaurant, much like what you'd expect in a typical Chinese restaurant in the shopping mall.The dishes were listed in a paper menu that you can tick and select the ones you'd want. The dim sum were mostly hits - the har gow, the siew mais, the chee cheong fun, they were all delicious. Don't forget to grab a few egg tarts, they run out of stock easily so you might want to make the order early.

Looking for some old school breakfast where there is no fuss about queues and high expectations? Zi Yean is the place to go with your whole village of relatives if you are not there sourcing for the best, but just plain comfort dim sum. Nothing fanciful, your usual siew mais and har kaos, but one thing to rave is the mei cai kou rou bun ( stewed preserved vegetables with pork). It is just the right balance of sweet and salty, with a fragrant garlic aroma when eaten hot. It is a simple bun, but it does make you want more. The siew mai uses finely diced lean meat rather than minced meat, giving it the textural bite and freshness often lacking in siew mais. For two person having a decent dim sum breakfast of 6 steamer trays, you would expect to pay about $25.
